衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
known as the International Association of Microbiologists), at its Fifth International . Congress in Rio de Janeiro recommended that the Centre's functions should be extended
1 to include work on escherichia. This was accepted by the WHO Executive Board in 1952, and the International Salmonella Centre accordingly became the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre .- 2
Under the terms of a formal Agreement, in respect of which the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre receives financial support from WHO, the Centre undertakes to:
"(a) collect, identify and type salmonella and escherichia strains;
(b) supply free of charge to national salmonella centres, salmonella and escherichia strains and diagnostic sera;
(c) carry out further research work in salmonella and the escherichia."
The International Shigella Centres, Atlanta and London. These also were, in effect, in existence prior to their formal establishment by WHO, which arose also from a request by the IAMS at its Congress in 1950. On recommendations from the Shigella Commission of the Enterobacteriaceae Subcommittee of the IAMS's International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature, and no doubt influenced by the fact that the London laboratory (temporarily in Oxford at the time) had already developed informal working relationships with appropriate laboratories in the British Commonwealth and Europe, and that the Atlanta laboratory had similar contacts in other parts of the world, the Congress asked WHO to establish these two central laboratories as International Shigella Centres with the same respective geographical contacts as they had already by then developed. The Centres were in due course established by WHO as from 1 January 1954. 3
4
1 Abstracts of the Fifth International Congress for Microbiology, published by the Instituto Oswald Cruz, Rio de Janeiro, 1950, p. 224; and Int. Bull. Bact. Nomen. & Taxon., 1951, 1, 137
2 WHO Executive Board Resolution EB9.RIO, 1952, Off. Rec. Wld H1th Org., 40, 5
3 Abstracts of the Fifth International Congress for Microbiology, 1950, p. 224; and Int. Bull Bact. Nomen, & Taxon., 1954, 4, 27
4 WHO Executive Board Resolution EB9.R62, 1952, Off. Rec. Wld Hlth Org., 40, 23
國史饭 Academia Historica

paragraphs.content: 衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
known as the International Association of Microbiologists), at its Fifth International . Congress in Rio de Janeiro recommended that the Centre's functions should be extended

1 to include work on escherichia. This was accepted by the WHO Executive Board in 1952, and the International Salmonella Centre accordingly became the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre .- 2
Under the terms of a formal Agreement, in respect of which the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre receives financial support from WHO, the Centre undertakes to:
"(a) collect, identify and type salmonella and escherichia strains;
(b) supply free of charge to national salmonella centres, salmonella and escherichia strains and diagnostic sera;
(c) carry out further research work in salmonella and the escherichia."

The International Shigella Centres, Atlanta and London. These also were, in effect, in existence prior to their formal establishment by WHO, which arose also from a request by the IAMS at its Congress in 1950. On recommendations from the Shigella Commission of the Enterobacteriaceae Subcommittee of the IAMS's International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature, and no doubt influenced by the fact that the London laboratory (temporarily in Oxford at the time) had already developed informal working relationships with appropriate laboratories in the British Commonwealth and Europe, and that the Atlanta laboratory had similar contacts in other parts of the world, the Congress asked WHO to establish these two central laboratories as International Shigella Centres with the same respective geographical contacts as they had already by then developed. The Centres were in due course established by WHO as from 1 January 1954. 3
1 Abstracts of the Fifth International Congress for Microbiology, published by the Instituto Oswald Cruz, Rio de Janeiro, 1950, p. 224; and Int. Bull. Bact. Nomen. & Taxon., 1951, 1, 137
2 WHO Executive Board Resolution EB9.RIO, 1952, Off. Rec. Wld H1th Org., 40, 5
3 Abstracts of the Fifth International Congress for Microbiology, 1950, p. 224; and Int. Bull Bact. Nomen, & Taxon., 1954, 4, 27
